1. Intrinsic Motivation Drives Deep Reading

  • At its core, people choose (and immerse themselves in) content that sparks intrinsic motivation—the internal drive to pursue something for its own sake, not external rewards like grades or likes. Psychologists like Edward Deci and Richard Ryan (in their Self-Determination Theory) explain this as happening when the material satisfies three needs: autonomy (you feel in control of your learning), competence (it helps you grow skills), and relatedness (it connects to your world or curiosity).
  • For Yin Wang’s blog, readers might dive in because his essays empower autonomy (e.g., “Learn by doing, not just theory”) and build competence (e.g., debugging life’s “bugs” through code-like thinking). If you’re studying programming or self-improvement, it feels like a direct tool for personal growth, unlike skimmable social media fluff. We read word-for-word because our brain rewards us with dopamine for “aha” moments—it’s like cracking a puzzle that matters to us.

2. Relevance and Personal Resonance

  • Choices like this often stem from relevance filtering: In a sea of information overload (average person sees 10,000+ ads and posts daily), we subconsciously prioritize what aligns with our goals, values, or current challenges. If someone’s navigating a PhD, career pivot, or learning curve (like you seem to be), Wang’s authentic journey—from academia to industry—mirrors their path. It’s not generic advice; it’s lived wisdom.
  • Research from cognitive science (e.g., Daniel Kahneman’s work on attention) shows we have limited “System 2” thinking (slow, deliberate focus). We reserve it for high-value stuff. Skimming is for low-stakes info; deep reading is for what could change your trajectory. Ask yourself: Does this help me avoid pitfalls I see in my life? That “yes” triggers careful attention.

3. Trust and Authenticity as Gatekeepers

  • People trust sources that feel genuine and unpolished. Wang’s blog stands out because it’s opinionated, reflective, and free from corporate spin—it’s him sharing unfiltered lessons (e.g., critiquing Big Tech or simplifying complex PL concepts). This builds cognitive trust, making readers linger.
  • Contrast this with clickbait: We bail on insincere content because it wastes our finite energy. Studies on reading comprehension (like those from the National Reading Panel) show that interest level predicts retention—genuinely hooked readers process 2-3x more deeply, remembering details word-for-word.

4. How to Cultivate or Analyze These Choices in Yourself/Others

  • Self-Reflection: Track what pulls you in. Journal: “What about Wang’s post on learning made me pause?” Often, it’s vulnerability (his failures) or applicability (applying PL theory to daily decisions). Tools like the “Interest Inventory” from education psych can help: Rate content on curiosity, usefulness, and enjoyment.
  • For Others: Observe patterns. Tech folks might devour Wang because it validates “thinking like a hacker” for life.   • Practical Tip: To encourage deep reading, curate feeds mindfully. Use RSS readers for blogs like Wang’s, and set “deep dive” sessions (e.g., 30 mins uninterrupted). Apps like Readwise can capture highlights to reinforce why it mattered.
